Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Starts
Notes: Any list of the most egregious IT project failures of the past ten years has to include the US Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System. ECSS was supposed to be a single integrated enterprise resource planning (ERP) system built using commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) software, and aimed at modernizing the service's global supply chain. The original estimated life-cycle  cost of ECSS was put at some $3.0 billion, about evenly split between development and operations and maintenance. The plan was to have a fully deployed system by 2012. (A note of caution—no one really has an authoritative set of financials on ECSS. That was made clear in the US Senate investigation report, which expressed frustration and outrage that the Air Force couldn’t tell it what was spent on what, when it was spent, nor even what ECSS had planned to spend over time. Various reports have conflicting data on estimated and spent costs.)
url: GAO-08-866 Air Force Asset Visibility http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d08866.pdf; GAO-13-311 Defense Major Automated Information Systems www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-311

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Contract Awarded
Notes: Computer Sciences Corp. is awarded one of the largest contracts, for $628 million. Oracle is also a contractor. The intended capabilities of ECSS are still a bit of a mystery. At this point in time, the Air Force said that ECSS was going to “replace more than 400 legacy systems..” Over time, that number jumped to “over 700 legacy systems[PDF]”.
url: Expeditionary Combat Support System: Root Cause Analysis (See Figure 3) www.acq.osd.mil/parca/docs/2011-ida-rca-ecss-p-4732.pdf

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Finances Get Murky
Notes: The 2008 GAO report says that the total life cycle cost is still $3 billion, but also notes that the Air Force acknowledges that the program is going to overrun that amount, because functionality that was supposed to go into the DEAMS project was now to be merged into ECSS.
url: Expeditionary Combat Support System: Root Cause Analysis (See Figure 3) www.acq.osd.mil/parca/docs/2011-ida-rca-ecss-p-4732.pdf

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Reality Check
Notes: By 2010, the cost of ECSS had jumped to $3.4 billion for development while operations and maintenance increased to $1.8 billion, and full deployment wasn’t now going to happen until 2016 at the earliest. The Air Force says ECSS will replace “over 500 legacy systems.” If the numbers given in a 2010 Institute of Defense Analysis (IDA) report (pdf) of ECSS is correct, some $5 billion plus in lost opportunity costs have been incurred so far, and it is likely another $7 billion or so at least will be incurred by the time a replacement system is put into place.

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Reassessed
Notes: In addition to the $876 million already spent, USAF had another $110 million worth of obligations they hadn't yet paid for. Now the Air Force says ECSS will replace just 240 legacy systems.

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Cancelled
Notes: The final “official” spending number for the program was reported in September, and it was cancelled in December 2012. Yet even the increased cost and schedule estimates were optimistic: after spending over $1 billion, the Air Force admitted that it would cost another $1 billion to get just 25% of the system’s planned capability. Additonally, you can tack on another $750 million in projected benefits that the project never delivered. A 2014 Senate investigative report into the debacle noted, “To date, the Air Force still cannot provide the exact number of legacy systems ECSS would have replaced.” In her testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee's Subcommittee on Readiness and Management Support in April 2012, the Air Force's comptroller, Jamie Morin said, “We're now approaching seven years since funds were first expended on this system. The total cost is now over US $1 billion. I'm personally appalled at the limited capabilities that program has produced relative to that amount of investment.” At the present time, an ECSS replacement is being planned, but how much it will cost and when it is expected to be operational the Air Force isn’t saying, although it is promising it will cost less than ECSS.Why did ECSS fail? There are three different publicly available reports (one from IDA (pdf), one from the Air Force (pdf) and one from the Senate(pdf) ) providing a host of reasons to choose from, but if one were sum them up, management incompetence coupled with excessive hubris and a desire not to hear negative news would probably capture 95% of it. While promising to learn the lessons from previous similar large-scale IT failures (its own as well as others in the Department of Defense), the Air Force management not only studiously ignored them by seemed to willfully defy them. And as the IDA report noted, bring up bad news required “courage.”Finally, who was held accountable for ECSS’s demise? No one as it turned out. The Air Force’s senior leadership made it crystal clear that firing or demoting anyone for blowing $1 billion on an absolutely useless IT system was “not necessary.” A candid statement if there ever was one that goes a long way towards explaining why no one in ECSS ever brought up bad news.
url: GAO-13-311 Defense Major Automated Information Systems www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-311

Headline: Contract Starts
Notes: North Carolina awards the first contract for a new Medicaid claims processing and management system called NCTracks. It is the second attempt, after spending $30 million on an earlier attempt.

Headline: Costly Delays
Notes: North Carolina spent at least $36 million (net)  to keep legacy system going because of the delay; Medicaid certification expected summer 2014, didn't happen until March 2015 because of extensive bugs in system.
The Disability Insurance Automation project was aimed to automate a number of manual work processes involved when filing for a disability insurance claim.
Procurement issues cause schedule slip but project cost reduced.

California Employment Development Department recognized that it had underestimated the complexity and effort required to create the system, so the project is rescoped. Deloitte will be paid $52 million to build system. Development now begins in earnest.
Project scope changes increase life cycle costs and schedule. Development costs climb another $7 million.
Launched "ahead" of schedule.

Califonia's Employment Development Department originally planned two system developments: the Call Center Network Platform and Application Upgrade
(CCNPAU), meant to TK, and the Continued Claims Redesign (CCR), intended to TK. The first of these was targeted for completion in 2006.

Califonia's Employment Development Department originally planned two system developments: the Call Center Network Platform and Application Upgrade
(CCNPAU), meant to TK, and the Continued Claims Redesign (CCR), intended to TK. The second had a larger budget and timeline.

Three years later, just a few months ahead of CCNPAU's original completion date, both projects were merged into one. Both projects still maintained separate schedules. CCNPAU completion was pushed back four years (longer than the initial scheduled development time.

A year later, due to changes in procurement, the cost of CCNPAU had risen yet again, but the timeline was reduced.
A year later, due to changes in procurement, the cost of CCNPAU had risen yet again, but the timeline was reduced. Meanwhile, CCR costs and delays continued to mount.
Another two years into the project, CCNPAU costs and delays were growing again.
Another two years into the project, CCNPAU costs and delays were growing again. But now CCR saw a schedule reduction! (The completion date was only moved up a single month, though).
CCNPAU was rolled out in May 2011, missing it's 2009 deadline by four months (and the original deadline by over four years). It wasn't a smooth launch; complaints about call wait times were rampant.

CCNPAU was rolled out in May 2011, missing it's 2009 deadline by four months (and the original deadline by over four years). It wasn't a smooth launch; complaints about call wait times were rampant. And CCR's launch was delayed by another year.

CCNPAU was rolled out in May 2011, missing it's 2009 deadline by four months (and the original deadline by over four years). It wasn't a smooth launch; complaints about call wait times were rampant. CCR was rolled out over Labor Day weekend, also four months off of its final deadline (but over five years late according to the original schedule). By the way, the launch was a total disaster LINK TK. Since launch, the state has spent approximately $4 million on upgrading and fixing CCR.

Fixed price contract to IBM was for $6.19 million for new payroll system at Queensland Health. This is part of a larger $98 million project contract to IBM to provided Queensland-wide human resources and financial solution.
Same estimated project cost, but an increase in schedule.
Slight increase in project cost and schedule.

Payroll system not close to being completed. IBM says cost to provide Queensland-wide human resources and financial solution is now $181 million, so that initiative is scrapped, with emphasis placed on getting Queensland health payroll system to work. IBM has spent $31 million of $98 million, including monies spent on payroll system.
Same estimated project cost, but an increase in schedule.

Project cost is increased, and scheduled lengthened. IBM paided $9 million for changes to payroll stystem changes, brings cost to $17 million.

Goes live with disastrous effects,  over 18,000 staff affected, 1800 not paid or underpaid; $14.5 million total in salaries glitches.  IBM cost for payroll system now is $25 million (it has been paid $22 million); government says total cost of payroll system including its own amounts to $102 million.
Govt decides to spend another $209 million to try to fix system
Govt claims payroll system is stabilized

Another $220.5 million needed to fix, and $837 million to operate for next 5 years; $91 million in salary overpayments still owed (note, a KPMG report says the development cost is closer to $515 million with another $25 million needed to see what other fixes are needed.) Estimate of total life cycle cost is at least $1.25 billion to $1.35 billion

FiReControl was to replacing 46 local control rooms with a network of nine purpose-built regional control centers using a national computer system to handle calls, mobilise equipment and manage incidents. Initial rollout was due in October 2007, and final by October 2009
Increase to the project cost but schedule unchanged.

Project terminated in December 2010 after spending £250 million and not impending much of value; another £219 million in already committed costs, so a total spend of £469 million; another £180 million could be spent, the May 2015 date was a best guess, since the program was still estimated to be at least 5 years from completion.
